newsitem.title: USA: U.S. adj retail sales up 2.5 pct in Feb - Redbook.
newsitem.headline: U.S. adj retail sales up 2.5 pct in Feb - Redbook.

text.p: U.S. seasonally adjusted retail sales rose 2.5 percent in the first week of fiscal February versus January, according to the Lynch, Jones & Ryan Inc Redbook Retail Sales Index.

The index rose 5.8 percent compared to the same month a year ago, the report said. Adjusted retail sales advanced 5.8 percent in the week ended February 8 compared with the same week a year ago, it said.
Much of the early-February gains appeared to be built upon the strength of apparel sales, said Howard Eilenberg, a retail analyst at Lynch, Jones & Ryan.
"Apparel is doing well, and that's encouraging," Eilenberg said in an interview with Reuters Financial Television.
In particular, higher-priced men's and women's clothing sold well, he said.

Chain and discount stores appeared to outperform department stores during the first week of the month, Eilenberg said. A snowstorm in the mid-Atlantic region may have depressed department store results, he said.
Looking ahead, February sales performance should cool somewhat but remain strong, and March looks like it will be in good shape, said Eilenberg.
"Easter is a little earlier this year, so you're going to see a stronger March," he said.
